figures.description: Production possibility diagram for Questions 11 and 12. Vertical axis: consumer goods; horizontal axis: capital goods. Two concave production possibility curves are drawn: an inner frontier labelled I and an outer frontier labelled II. Point P lies on curve I. Movement from curve I to curve II represents an outward shift of the production possibility frontier (economic growth).

Short‑run cost diagram for Question 13 labelled 'Graph of costs'. Vertical axis measures cost and horizontal axis measures quantity of output per period. Four U‑shaped curves are drawn and labelled I, II, III and IV. One of them represents the firm's short‑run average variable cost curve (SAVC).

Perfect‑competition cost diagram for Question 20. Vertical axis: cost; horizontal axis: quantity. A U‑shaped average‑cost curve lies above a short‑run marginal‑cost curve labelled SMC. A horizontal line through the diagram is labelled AR = MR = P, representing the perfectly elastic demand faced by the firm. The AR line intersects SMC at point F. The minimum point of the AC curve is G. Vertical coordinates M and N mark different cost levels on the axis.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: With a given level of money income, a consumer maximizes satisfaction from the consumption of goods and services when

options.text: total utility derived from each good or service is increasing at an increasing rate
marginal utility derived from each good or service is increasing at the same rate
marginal utility derived per naira spent is the same for all the goods and services
total utility derived from all the goods and services is large

questions.explanation: The **equi‑marginal principle** states that a consumer maximizes utility when \(MU_x/P_x = MU_y/P_y = \dots\) for all goods.

questions.question: Ike’s scale of preference reveals that he prefers bananas to pawpaw, pawpaw to oranges and oranges to bananas. Ike’s preferences are therefore
questions.explanation: His preferences are **cyclical** (banana ≻ pawpaw ≻ orange ≻ banana), violating transitivity and thus inconsistent.

questions.question: One of the features of a free market economy is that

options.text: resources are directed by the price mechanism
workers do not earn equal wages
the profit motive is severely constrained
decisions on the economy are taken by bureaucratic structures

questions.explanation: In a market economy, the **price mechanism** allocates resources.

questions.question: One of the fundamental differences between a capitalist and a socialist economy is that while

options.text: the former is characterized by complete government ownership of resources, the latter is characterized by complete private ownership
in the former, prices act as signals in the allocation of resources; in the latter, it is the central authority that performs this function
taxes are levied in a capitalist economy; there is no taxation in a socialist economy
income and wealth are equally distributed in the socialist economy; this is not so in a capitalist economy

questions.explanation: Capitalism relies on **price signals** for resource allocation, whereas socialism relies on **central planning**.

questions.question: Given that at the beginning of 1973, Nigeria with a population of 75 million had a birth rate of 3% per annum. This implies that in that year

options.text: the government had to make provisions for 2.25 million children

questions.explanation: Births = \(0.03 \times 75\text{ million} = 2.25\text{ million}\).

questions.question: When a country’s population is experiencing increasing returns, that country is said to be
questions.explanation: Increasing returns to population imply that output per head rises as population grows; this is characteristic of an **under‑populated** country.

questions.question: In a country, if the proportion of people who are below 15 years is 45% and those above 60 years is 30%, this implies that the

options.text: population is growing according to Malthus theory

questions.explanation: A large share of young and old (non‑working) people means a **high dependency ratio**.

questions.question: One of the objectives of Nigeria’s current population policy is to
questions.explanation: Nigeria’s population policy seeks to **slow population growth**, mainly by reducing fertility.

questions.question: Labour productivity is the ratio of
questions.explanation: Productivity of labour is **output per worker per hour**, i.e. \(\text{output} / \text{man‑hours}\).

questions.question: The type of cost which has to be covered for a firm to continue production in the short run is the
questions.explanation: The shutdown condition is \(P \geq AVC\); the firm must at least cover **average variable cost**.

questions.question: Referring to the production‑possibility diagram in figure Econ1997_PPC_I_II, the current stage of the economy is depicted in curve I. Point P suggests that the economy is

options.text: reaching full employment but not full production
attaining full production but not full employment
attaining both full employment and full production

questions.explanation: The exact location of point P relative to curves I and II is not sufficiently clear in the scan to determine whether it indicates unemployment (inside the curve) or full utilization (on the curve).

questions.question: The movement of curve I to II in figure Econ1997_PPC_I_II suggests

options.text: an improvement in capital‑goods technology but not in consumer‑goods technology
a movement from unemployment to full employment
that the output for society has declined
a gain in consumer‑goods technique and not in capital‑goods technique

questions.explanation: An outward shift of the PPF generally indicates **economic growth** (improvement in technology and/or resources). The options in the low‑resolution scan are ambiguous; a precise choice cannot be made without a clearer copy.

questions.question: In the cost diagram of figure Econ1997_SAC_Curves, the curve which represents the firm’s short‑run average variable cost is curve
questions.explanation: Without a clearer reproduction of the four curves (average fixed, average variable, average total and marginal cost), it is not possible to state confidently which is the SAVC curve.

questions.question: A good is said to be inferior if its demand
questions.explanation: For an **inferior good**, income elasticity is negative: demand falls as income rises.

questions.question: Given a market demand curve \(Q_d = 120 - 2P\) and a supply curve \(Q_s = 4P\), the equilibrium price and quantity respectively are
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, \(Q_d = Q_s\): \(120 - 2P = 4P \Rightarrow 120 = 6P \Rightarrow P = 20\). Then \(Q = 4P = 80\).

questions.question: If a demand curve that intersects a perfectly inelastic supply curve shifts rightward, then

options.text: the equilibrium price and quantity will increase

questions.explanation: With a **vertical supply curve**, quantity is fixed; a rightward shift in demand raises only the **price**.

questions.question: The elasticity of demand for a firm’s product is 2. If the firm reduces its prices by 20 per cent, its sales revenue will increase by
questions.explanation: Elasticity \(e = 2 = \frac{\%\Delta Q}{\%\Delta P}\). A 20% price cut implies \(\%\Delta P = -20\%\) and \(\%\Delta Q = 2 \times (-20\%) = +40\%\). Change in revenue ≈ \(\%\Delta P + \%\Delta Q = -20\% + 40\% = +20\%\).

questions.question: If the percentage change in the income of the consumers of an industrial product is less than the resulting percentage change in the quantity demanded of the product, then the income elasticity of demand for the product is
questions.explanation: Income elasticity \(E_y = \frac{\%\Delta Q}{\%\Delta Y}\). If \(|\%\Delta Q| > |\%\Delta Y|\), then \(|E_y| > 1\): a **luxury good**.

questions.question: A market where there are many differentiated products is called
questions.explanation: In **monopolistic competition**, many firms sell differentiated products.

questions.question: Refer to the perfect‑competition cost diagram in figure Econ1997_PerfComp_Cost. From the diagram, the profit‑maximizing quantity of output is determined by the point
questions.explanation: A competitive firm maximizes profit where **\(MC (SMC) = MR = P\)**; this intersection is labelled F.

questions.question: The best channel of distribution of baked bread is through

options.text: wholesalers to retailers then to consumers

questions.explanation: Because bread is **perishable and low‑value**, a short channel—**retailers to consumers**—is most appropriate.

questions.question: A form of business organization which is characterized by limited authority and liability of the individual owners is the
questions.explanation: In a **joint‑stock (limited‑liability) company**, shareholders have limited liability and delegate authority to managers.

questions.question: The shares that must be redeemed first at liquidation of a company are
questions.explanation: Although not technically shares, **debentures** (bondholders) are repaid before any class of shareholders at liquidation.

questions.question: The suggestion that peasants in Africa have backward‑bending supply curves of output implies that their response to an increase in the price of their crops will be to
questions.explanation: With a **backward‑bending supply curve**, higher prices allow farmers to meet income targets with **less output**, so they reduce supply.

questions.question: The most important requirement for increasing agricultural output in Nigeria is

options.text: for government to go into large‑scale farming
to employ relevant foreign technology and reform the land tenure system
to increase farmers’ incomes and improve farming techniques

questions.explanation: Higher **incentives for farmers and improved techniques** are central to raising output.

questions.question: What is the effect of inelastic demand for agricultural products on the income of a farmer?

options.text: a price rise results in its fall
a price rise results in its rise
a price fall results in its rise
a price rise leaves the income unchanged

questions.explanation: With **inelastic demand**, total revenue (and hence income) moves in the **same direction as price**.

questions.question: Plywood industries are often located near the source of
questions.explanation: Plywood production uses bulky timber, so firms locate close to **raw‑material sources**.

questions.question: A firm is said to have benefited from external economies in production if it has realized

options.text: a more efficient management of resources
a better combination of factors of production
reduced resource costs due to operations of other firms
a higher profits level due to increased sales

questions.explanation: External economies are **cost reductions** arising from industry‑wide expansion or spillovers from other firms.

questions.question: One of the dangers of the localization of industries is
questions.explanation: Regions dependent on a few localized industries are vulnerable to **structural unemployment** if those industries decline.

questions.question: A glut in the world market for crude oil means

options.text: an excess supply of crude petroleum
a higher crude‑oil price offered by the buyer
a higher crude‑oil price demanded by the seller

questions.explanation: A **glut** is an excess supply over demand.

questions.question: The main problem of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is how to

options.text: prevent members from violating their quota
enhance the quality of petroleum products
compete with the North Sea producers

questions.explanation: OPEC’s effectiveness depends on **members adhering to production quotas**.

questions.question: The most important attribute of money is
questions.explanation: To function as money, an item must be **widely accepted** in payment for goods and debts.

questions.question: Which of the following is inflationary?
questions.explanation: Higher government spending raises aggregate demand and tends to be **inflationary**.

questions.question: In commercial banking, an account from which the customer cannot withdraw money instantly is a
questions.explanation: **Time deposits** (fixed deposits) require notice before withdrawal.

questions.question: Banks can create more money by

options.text: increasing their cash ratio with the Central Bank
lending out money from customers’ deposits

questions.explanation: Through the **credit‑creation process**, banks lend a fraction of deposits, which then become deposits elsewhere.

questions.question: Stocks and shares as well as bonds are examples of instruments used in the
questions.explanation: Long‑term securities like **shares and bonds** are traded in **capital markets**.

questions.question: The use of legally permissible means to reduce tax liabilities is known as tax
questions.explanation: Using loopholes within the law to reduce tax is **tax avoidance**.

questions.question: The greatest proportion of government revenue in Nigeria comes from

options.text: income taxes on individuals and businesses
loans and grants from industrially advanced countries

questions.explanation: Historically, Nigeria’s public revenue has been dominated by **oil and other raw‑material exports**.

questions.question: One of the factors which is likely to check the growth of public debts is
questions.explanation: A **debt‑equity swap** converts debt into equity investments, reducing outstanding public debt.

questions.question: If the marginal propensity to consume is 0.75 and private investment increases by N10 billion while government expenditure decreases by N15 billion, GDP will decrease by
questions.explanation: Net change in autonomous spending: \(\Delta A = +10 - 15 = -5\) billion. Multiplier \(k = 1/(1-0.75) = 4\). So \(\Delta Y = k\Delta A = 4 \times (-5) = -20\) billion.

questions.question:
Given: 
Investment \(I = \text{N}100\) million, 
Consumption \(C = 200m + 0.75Y\), 
Income \(Y = C + I\). 
What is the equilibrium income level (to the nearest million)?
questions.explanation: Substitute: \(Y = (200 + 0.75Y) + 100\). So \(Y - 0.75Y = 300 \Rightarrow 0.25Y = 300 \Rightarrow Y = 1,200\) million.

questions.question: The total money values of all goods and services produced in a country during a certain period is measured by using the
questions.explanation: This description fits the **output (product) method** of measuring national income.

questions.question: Privatization of government‑owned companies means the

options.text: relinquishing of government’s equity participation to private individuals
joint participation of government and private individuals
commercialization and deregulation of the economy

questions.explanation: Privatization involves **selling government shares** to private investors.

questions.question: The major determinant of the total volume of output in an economy is the
questions.explanation: In Keynesian analysis, short‑run output is determined by **aggregate demand (total expenditure)**.

questions.question: The most important factor in ensuring economic development is the

options.text: attraction of foreign aids and grants

questions.explanation: Sustained development requires **high domestic savings and investment**.

questions.question: Which of the following classes of goods accounts for the largest proportion of Nigeria’s imports?
questions.explanation: Nigeria’s import bill is dominated by **capital goods and transport equipment**.

questions.question: Counter‑trading is an international arrangement whereby

options.text: goods and services are exchanged in a manner similar to barter
goods and services are sold on the counter
crude oil is sold to a foreign country
goods are shipped to countries on which the United Nations has placed a trade embargo

questions.explanation: Counter‑trade involves **barter‑like exchanges of goods and services**, often used when currencies are scarce.

questions.question:
In recent years, Nigeria’s balance of payments has continued to register a deficit due to
I. increased government overseas spending.
II. increasing prices of exports.
III. rising import prices.
IV. more payments to overseas investors.
questions.explanation: High overseas spending, rising import prices and more interest/dividend payments **worsen the balance of payments**; rising export prices would usually improve it.

questions.question: The organization which provides credits to help countries achieve short‑term balance in their balance of payments is the

options.text: Economic Community of West African States
International Bank for Reconstruction and Development

questions.explanation: The **IMF** provides short‑term balance‑of‑payments support.

questions.question: An important feature of a cartel is that

options.text: members do not reduce price below the cartel price
each member has a fixed output above which it is not expected to produce
a powerful member fixes the price at which others will sell
members fix the prices for their products

questions.explanation: In a **cartel**, firms collude to fix prices (and often output) instead of competing.
